text: - Hello, my name is Devabrat Kumar,
and I'm a Product Manager on Amazon S3.

In this presentation, I'm
excited to talk to you
about Mountpoint for Amazon S3.

Mountpoint for Amazon S3 is
a new open-source file client

that makes it easy for
Linux-based applications
to connect directly to Amazon S3 buckets
and access objects using file APIs.
Using Mountpoint for Amazon S3,
you can mount your Amazon S3 bucket

on your compute instance
and it presents S3 objects
as files in the local file system.
It translates local file system API calls
to rest API calls on Amazon S3 objects.
With Mountpoint for Amazon S3,

you can achieve high
single-instance throughput
to finish jobs faster.

You can reliably scale up
and down over thousands

of instances and read large
objects processing petabytes
of data in S3 data lakes.
With Mountpoint being generally available,

it is ready for use with
your production workloads.
It comes with AWS support.
This means customers with AWS business

and Enterprise support
plans get 24/7 access
to cloud-support engineers
to support their use of Mountpoint.

Mountpoint for Amazon S3
is ideal for large-scale
out workloads that process petabyes

of data using random and
sequential read operations

and sequential write operations
for creating new files.

Common use cases include
machine learning training,
autonomous vehicle simulation,
genomics analysis, and image rendering.

These applications perform
read-heavy access on hundreds

of terabytes to petabytes
of data in S3 data lakes,
and require S3's high elastic throughput

as they scale up and down
over thousands of instances.

While they read large files
over one onboard instance,

they write to a file from a
single instance at a time.

This means they do not need
shared file system features
like file locking.

However, if you are looking
to run data lake applications
that need to collaborate or coordinate
on shared data across instances or users,

we recommend using Amazon FSx
for Lustre with Amazon S3.

But if you're running
a data lake application
that needs to read and write large objects
without shared file system features
like locking or POSIX permissions,

we recommend using
Mountpoint for Amazon S3.
Next, let's see Mountpoint in action,

and see how it works for
your Amazon S3 buckets.
As you can see, I have Mountpoint
already installed on my EC2 instance.

The first thing that I do
is to create a directory

where I'm going to mount my
S3 bucket calling it mntdir.
Next, I'm going to use Mountpoint

to mount my S3 bucket
at this mount location.
With Mountpoint running in the background,

my directory now reflects
the content of my S3 bucket.
Here we can see that Mountpoint creates

a directory structure using
the keys of my S3 objects.

Now, I can use common
Linux command line tools
with my S3 objects.
For example, I can create an archive file
using the tag command,
so I can say tar, let's call it test.gz.

And I'm going to use
files from my S3 bucket

which is mounted at this
new directory location
that I have created just now.
So I have a bunch of PDFs here,

and I'm going to create an
archive file called test.gz.
Behind the scenes, Mountpoint is streaming
my objects directly from S3,
so that I don't need to do any manual work

like copying my files down
to my local storage first.
I can just run my command as if the files
were already on my local disc.

Let's quickly look at the
archive file that I just created.
So there it is.
Next I can write this file

to the bucket as if it
is a local file system.

So I can do cp test.gz and
then the mount location

where I want to write it to
which is just my S3 bucket.
I can quickly verify using AWS CLI.

So I'm just going to do a
list command on my S3 bucket

and see that this file was
actually written there,
so there it is.

With mount one, customers can
run business-specific tools,

like ffmpeg while accessing
S3 as a local file system.

For example, I can run
ffmpeg and then let's say,
I want to downscale a file
that I have stored in my S3 bucket.

I'm choosing this
machine-learning session from one

of our previous reinvents, and
I'm going to scale it down.
Let's say to 480 is to 320,
and I'm going to save the result
on my local instance in this case.
So let's just call it scale result.mp4,
and let's just run this command.
So again, behind the scenes,

Mountpoint is streaming my
object directly from S3,
so that I don't need to do any manual work
like copying it down.
And I can see the result here,
the file that was created just now.
Thus, we see you can use Mountpoint

to access your S3 bucket
as a local file system
and use standard Linux commands
as well as business specific tools on it.

Finally, I'm unmounting my
bucket from this location,
and you can use it for any other purpose.
With this, we conclude our demo today.
We are really excited as you get started

with Mountpoint, and we are
looking forward to hearing
from you on how you use Mountpoint
for your production use cases.
Thank you.
